fields.description: Nested Variables plugin is a third party plugin, but we generate the license for it because the license has to match with the Bamboo license. For example, if someone has a 1 remote agent Bamboo license, then he needs to buy/use 1 remote agent license for the Nested Variables plugin. The default version of the UPM (2.0.6) that is shipped with Bamboo 4.2.1 works fine, but the latest version of the UPM (2.7.7) allows to successfully apply the license and shows that it is not compatible with the Bamboo license. Also, the plugin doesn't work. After reverting the UPM back to 2.0.6, everything starts working again.
fields.summary: UPM version 2.7.7 shows incompatibility for a correct license of Bamboo Nested Variables Plugin

fields.description:
When adding an executable, the path parameter has a caption "Please enter the path to your executable" which will literally mean adding the absolute path to the executable itself. For some executables such as the Maven this will lead to some subtle errors as Bamboo will assume the path location as the home and append an /bin/mvn. Here is an example:

Added path: /usr/local/apache-maven/apache-maven-3.0.4 /bin/mvn

Bamboo will translate to the following at build time:

/usr/local/apache-maven/apache-maven-3.0.4 /bin/mvn/bin/mvn
fields.summary: Change the wordings of the path parameter when adding executable

fields.description:
Our Bamboo instance keeps consuming more and more memory accumulated in old generation. At the end it goes into a loop of Major GC and becomes almost unresponsive. Attaching GC chart (pink represents old generation)

We have only few builds, this is not a busy machine. Attaching GC logs. We captured heap dump but are reluctant to reveal it as it might contain some sensitive information like SVN credentials.

However we did some analysis using JProfiler and it seems that: {{com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.svn.SVNClientManagerFactory.clientManagers}} {{ArrayList}} holds 25 thousand instances of {{org.tmatesoft.svn.core.wc.SVNClientManager}}. This collection occupies 1,2 GB in total.

fields.description:
I created a new project, DEBUG, which has four plans in it: MASTER, SLAVE1, SLAVE2, and SLAVE3. All three slaves are dependencies of MASTER. Each of the four plans has a single job which runs the script, timeloop.rb. Each of those jobs requires an agent with "Debugger=1". There are only two agents (local) with that capability.

Timeloop.rb takes a single command line argument. The script loops for the number of times specified by that argument. The loop sleeps for 1 second then prints a message. At the end of the script, it prints a line indicating that the script has finished. In MASTER, timeloop.rb is set to run for 5 seconds. SLAVE1, SLAVE2, and SLAVE3 are set for 30, 60, and 90 respectively.

If when MASTER is run, it runs 5 seconds, then ends and queues all three slaves. SLAVE1 and 2 run immediately, SLAVE3 remains queued. When the script in SLAVE1 ends, Bamboo waits for SLAVE2 to end before starting SLAVE3.

timeloop.rb
{code}
$stdout.sync = true

time = ARGV[0].to_i

for i in 0..time
	sleep 1
	puts "Sleeping " + i.to_s + "\n";
end

puts "timeloop.rb finished\n"
{code}
fields.summary: When running 2 plans in parallel, Bamboo waits for both to finish before a new one can start

fields.summary: URLs for browsing artifact folders are a little funny

fields.description:
If a build is configured with one or more manual stages, it is difficult to find the last time any of those stages were attempted. Bamboo should provide a link on the main plan summary screen to the last attempted and successful complete builds, not just the last build to successfully reach a manual trigger point.

Bamboo should also provide a way to filter the build history for which stages were attempted or successful.
fields.summary: Make it easy to get to the last build that completed each manual stage

fields.description:
In Bamboo 4.2.0 build 3211, adding a build to the queue via the REST API, for example like this:

$ curl -X POST -u someone:password http://server:8085/rest/api/latest/queue/FOO-BAR

does not return any data, instead returning a 204 No Content response. This is inconsistent with what the documentation (http://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/4.0/#idp263696) claims should happen.

This does, however, work correctly on my local testing installation (v4.0, build 2906).
fields.summary: Queueing build via REST API does not return any data

fields.description:
Please document how Bamboo cache works. This should include the changes that happen to the state of Bamboo cache. How it should be configured, how/when  it gets updated, what exactly is saved in the cache and so on. Include specifics when Bamboo is integrated with LDAP, Crowd or JIRA.

Also, include a section for regular user login sessions and timeout configurations.
fields.summary: Documentation for Bamboo's user cache

- Configure Plan Branch on it with Gatekeeper and push enabled
- Add a file to a branch, commit & push (important: do not _modify_ any files: that works)
- Run Branch

Result: bamboo claims merge is correct, nothing appears on origin/master

At this point I'm no sure if it's relevant if merge is fast-forward -> test both scenarios

fields.description:
We've got a pretty busy Bamboo instance (actually we've got three with a fourth due soon), but on our primary instance, the "VARIABLE_CONTEXT" table is taking up 72% of the on-disk space of the database. This is not a problem in and of itself, but couple this with the fact that the database is 47GB in size, with that single table representing 34GB, and we have a problem.

This is problem for memory usage (we can no longer fit MySQL completely in memory), and also for the size of nightly complete and hourly incremental backups.

fields.description:
In the Stash team, we sometimes uses the _Re-run failing builds_ option to fix a red build to make it green and allows its dependent builds (like _Stash Deploy_) to run.

However when doing so, we loose the name(s) of the flaky test(s) that was or were failing. As a developer, it would be intuitive if Bamboo would record a list of tests that were failing but became green after a build re-run. The list could also contain a link to the re-run builds for each test, although that's optional.

This would permit a team of developers to have a list of known flaky tests that they can fix, and make it part of the team workflow.
fields.summary: Records flakey tests fixed by a re-run

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
- create a plan with 2 jobs
- make 1st job launch a script that wait 30s
- make 2nd job launch a script that wait 60s
- create 2 local agents
- launch a plan

You'll notice that both jobs end at the same time (after 60s). Problem happens randomly but quite often
Switching debugging on + looking at process explorer shows that the 1st process ends after 30s but bamboo continues to read its output stream for the next 30s. (getting nothing out of it just waiting for EOF)
fields.summary: If 2 processes start at once, the one ending earlier waits for the other to end. (Windows)

The existing branch build plans are still using the repository information that was current when the branch plan was created.

Because the original repository was removed most of the branch builds now fail and Bamboo keeps trying to retrieve repository information from the repository that doesn't exist anymore.

This should be used when the notification is set to "Send email to Responsible User". Which means that the responsible user should be tracked via the plan dependency line and get notified.

fields.description:
In the event that the option to "clean working directory" after build is enabled, the WD is cleaned regardless of success or failure status of the stage; unfortunately, this makes diagnosing environmental issues on an agent more difficult ... What would be nice would be the option to "clean working directory on success, snapshot working directory and attach to build results on failure" ...

This way, the WD is still guaranteed to be clean for the next run, but the state of the working directory on a failed build is captured at the point of failure.

fields.description:
This requires a change in Apache SSHD (it does not support it). We can also wait until they support it and upgrade.

Bamboo is not able to authenticate against SSH servers configured with the following settings :
ChallengeResponseAuthentication yes # interactively entered passwords
PasswordAuthentication no #non-interactively acquired passwords

In this context, both methods are essentially the same, i.e. enabling either of them means that users will be able to authenticate using a password.
In SSH protocol, however, they are completely different and have separate names. One is used to indicate that the password has been entered by the user and the other that it was not. 'Security people' tell other people to leave only the 'interactive' method enabled to prevent automated attacks against passwords. This is does not really help in any way, because creation of an ssh client pretending that the password was entered 'interactively' by the user is a trivial exercise for any C programmer with access to SSH sources.

Because Bamboo does not let people enter a password interactively, it honestly tells that server that it uses 'PasswordAuthentication' method of SSH protocol and the server will reject it.
To avoid that problem, you can either:
 # set PasswordAuthentication to yes 
 # configure Bamboo to use the non-native client (not recommended).
 # use key based authentication instead of password
fields.summary: Support keyboard-interactive authentication option of SSH

fields.description:
The basic requirement to quarantine or unleash a failed test is to have the plan administrator permission as mentioned in https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Quarantining+failing+tests . We have however noticed that this is not the case as the unleash button is only visisble to users with admin global permission.

*Steps to reproduce*
# Grant some users plan admin priviledges by navigating to the page https://localhost:8085/chain/admin/config/editChainPermissions.action?buildKey=PROJKEY-PLANKEY
# Quarantine some failed tests
# Login as one of the user granted permissions in step 1
# Visit the page https://localhost:8085/browse/PROJKEY-PLANKEY/quarantine

*expectation*
All quarantined test will be listed with option to unleash

*Current behaviour*
The unleash button is missing. However, users with global admin privileges will see the button. It is important to note that the unleash button will be visible to plan admins when viewing a specific build result summary eg https://localhost:8085/browse/PROJKEY-PLANKEY-X
fields.summary: Plan Administrators cannot see Unleash buttons on Quarantined Tests page

fields.description: I have a number of scripts which I provide as build services on a CI system. These scripts accept parameters which could be passed from the Bamboo interface when a build is invoked. As these scripts are never run for the same purpose twice in a row I would like to be able to force a plan to always run as though the user had clicked 'run customised'.
fields.summary: Ability to force a plan to always 'run customised'

fields.description:
Some small improvements would greatly enhance the utility of Bamboo for 'non-build' activities.  We have recently migrated from ThoughtWorks Go to Bamboo and this is the one area of (slight) weakness I have found in Bamboo.

1) Run Customized Plan should be a first-class citizen and get it's own run button (or perhaps the option of one for plans where it is applicable).

OR

A (Manually triggered) Plan should be able to be configured so that it can ONLY run with customization.  This stops operators hitting the run button on a Plan that will fail because not all parameters are specified.  (e.g. a Plan which deploys a database snapshot onto a DEV VM.  There are N possible targets and it seems clumsy to have have N clones of the Plan when we can use a Variable as a parameter to the Plan.


2) Configuration parameters should support array values which render as pick-lists in Run-Configured dialog.
fields.summary: Ability to show 'Run customised' all the time

fields.description: Add a shared user credentials feature to Bamboo, similar to what Bamboo already has with shared repositories, so that there's a central place for user/password data. When you create a source repository that needs authentication, you can select the shared credentials from a drop down box "Authentication type" so there's no need to enter user and password directly.

Bamboo 4.2.2 shipped with UPM 2.0.6 which is rather old. Additionally, it does not handle Marketplace plugins correctly (see https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/UPM-1917 for more info about this).

Please update to UPM 2.7.5 in Bamboo 4.3 such that Marketplace plugins will work with the bundled UPM. This is the same version that JIRA 5.2 and Confluence 5.0 have bumped to. Thanks!

cc [~jnolen], [~jkodumal]
fields.summary: Bamboo Marketplace plugins do not work with the bundled UPM version

fields.description:
We have just been building some EC2 server images for Windows/VS2012 CI servers triggered through bamboo (see http://davidstringeratwork.wordpress.com/2012/10/04/using-atlassian-bamboo-ondemand-for-visual-studio-2012-projects-part-1/). We built an AMI image of the CI server and configured bamboo to launch that when we committed to GITHub.
We encountered a problem when we added some other, non-transient instances to help with specialist testing.  At that point, our automated CI builds would no longer trigger. We were helped out by the support folks to identify that the problem related to the "number of elastic instances on your AWS account that are not controlled by Bamboo does not exceed" setting in the bamboo configuration. Once we had some more running instances we had exceeded this value so bamboo would not launch any more instances, even though the instances were for different purposes.
Support informed us that all running instances would count towards the "number of elastic instances" and gave us 3 different scenarios where it might be relevant. For our purposes, this bamboo configuration setting should just relate to instances started from AMI images that are launched by bamboo rather than all instances regardless of the AMI from which they originate. What we would like is a way of telling bamboo (or bamboo working it out) which image types it can (or has been able to) launch and only including these in the count.
fields.summary: Elastic bamboo should only consider bamboo instances when counting running instances

fields.description:

But I didn't find another way to do it.

I guess referencing a variable for the API key is something that customers would want to do, so it might worth finding out how it works.
fields.summary: Support referencing variables for Heroku API key

fields.description:
!https://extranet.atlassian.com/download/attachments/2013305598/run-with-revision.png?modificationDate=1343797439081&effects=border-simple,blur-border!

* An empty text input should mean that we will use the latest revision.
* In this dialog we should re-use the same Variables widget that we use to override variables in the Branch config and NOT the one from JBAM.
* the inline overriding of Stages: We already have this in the current dialog (hidden in a tab) - all we are doing is moving all of the operations onto a single screen.
* What do we want to do if there's a long list of stages? Anything? Just scroll? Maybe switch the order of the fields around? -> For the moment, we should just scroll.
* You can only specify revisions for the default repository (for the moment)

fields.description:
Amazon recently announced new services available in their ITAR-compliant "GovCloud" and Elastic Bamboo isn't now usable with GovCloud. Please implement this functionality.

Here's the announcement:

Dear Amazon Web Services Customer,

Announcing new services and features in AWS GovCloud (US)

We are excited to announce that a number of new features and services are now available in the AWS GovCloud (US) region, including Amazon EC2 Cluster Compute instances, Elastic Load Balancing, Auto Scaling, Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS), Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) and Amazon CloudWatch alarms.

The AWS GovCloud (US) Region

These new services and features are available in AWS GovCloud (US). AWS GovCloud (US) is an AWS Region designed to allow US government agencies and customers to move more sensitive workloads into the cloud by addressing their specific regulatory and compliance requirements. The AWS GovCloud (US) framework adheres to U.S. International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) requirements. Workloads that are appropriate for the AWS GovCloud (US) region include all categories of Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI), including ITAR, as well as Government oriented publically available data.

For AWS GovCloud (US) Region pricing, please see AWS GovCloud (US) pricing details.

To learn more, please visit our AWS GovCloud (US) home page.

Sincerely,
The Amazon Web Services Team
fields.summary: Elastic Bamboo support for Amazon EC2 GovCloud

fields.description:
My plan is configured this way:

* Source Repository: 
** Type: Subversion
** URL: file:///D:/Atlassian/Repositories/SVN/branches/branch2

* Default Job:
** Task 1: Source Code Checkout
*** Repository: Subversion
*** Checkout Directory: 
{noformat}
${bamboo.repository.branch.name}
{noformat}
** Task 2: Script
*** Script Location: Inline
*** Script Body:
{noformat}
echo "${bamboo.repository.branch.name} Done"
{noformat}

When I run the build, this is the result:
{noformat}
11-Out-2012 15:14:07	Starting task 'Checkout Default Repository' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.checkout'
11-Out-2012 15:14:07	Running preRetrieveSourceCode task...
11-Out-2012 15:14:08	Updating source code to revision: 15
11-Out-2012 15:14:08	Existing workspace found at 'D:\Atlassian\atlassian-bamboo-4.2.1\bamboo_home\xml-data\build-dir\PROJ-PLAN-JOB1\${bamboo.repository.branch.name}'. updating...
11-Out-2012 15:14:09	Updated source code to revision: 15
11-Out-2012 15:14:09	Running postRetrieveSourceCode task...
11-Out-2012 15:14:09	Finished task 'Checkout Default Repository'
...

11-Out-2012 15:14:09	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.repository.branch.name} with branch2
...
11-Out-2012 15:14:09	Starting task 'Shell Command' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.scripttask:task.builder.script'
11-Out-2012 15:14:09	D:\Atlassian\atlassian-bamboo-4.2.1\bamboo_home\xml-data\build-dir\PROJ-PLAN-JOB1>echo "branch2 Done" 
11-Out-2012 15:14:09	"branch2 Done"
11-Out-2012 15:14:09	Finished task 'Shell Command'
{noformat}

As can be seen, the code was checked out / updated into this directory:
{noformat}
BAMBOO_HOME\xml-data\build-dir\PROJ-PLAN-JOB1\${bamboo.repository.branch.name}
{noformat}
Note that the variable was not replaced by its value, which should be {{branch2}}.

The interesting thing is that, if I invert the order of the tasks, making the Script task run *before* the Source Code Checkout, the build result is the expected:
{noformat}
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.repository.branch.name} with branch2
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	Starting task 'Shell Command' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.scripttask:task.builder.script'
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	D:\Atlassian\atlassian-bamboo-4.2.1\bamboo_home\xml-data\build-dir\PROJ-PLAN-JOB1>echo "branch2 Done" 
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	"branch2 Done"
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	Finished task 'Shell Command'
...
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	Starting task 'Checkout Default Repository' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.checkout'
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	Running preRetrieveSourceCode task...
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	Updating source code to revision: 15
11-Out-2012 15:15:59	Working directory 'D:\Atlassian\atlassian-bamboo-4.2.1\bamboo_home\xml-data\build-dir\PROJ-PLAN-JOB1\branch2' is empty. Checking out SVN URL 'file:///D:/Atlassian/Repositories/SVN/branches/branch2'
11-Out-2012 15:16:00	Updated source code to revision: 15
11-Out-2012 15:16:00	Running postRetrieveSourceCode task...
11-Out-2012 15:16:00	Finished task 'Checkout Default Repository'
{noformat}
As can be seen here, the source code was checked out into the correct directory:
{noformat}
BAMBOO_HOME\xml-data\build-dir\PROJ-PLAN-JOB1\branch2
{noformat}
fields.summary: Checkout directory created incorrectly if the variable is not echoed first

fields.description:
I have a build that I want to check out a different svn directory each time.  I've put a ${tagname} in the path, which needs to be set using "Run Customised Build".

The first time I ran this it worked fine.  But the first time we ran it with a different variable it failed.

It failed particularly with a 404 when it attempted to check out from subversion

h3. Workaround
I'm told we can work around this by specifying the revision number to bypass the checking for changes that's causing the failure.
fields.summary: Second build with a svn source repo using a bamboo variable fails unhelpfully.

fields.description: Maybe we can add a field for each task for managing return codes. Let's say we can specify a list of return codes for which that specific task doesn't fail (as currently tasks will fail for any non-zero return code).
fields.summary: Allow to configure return codes for Bamboo executables

fields.description:
JIRA Bamboo plugin can't build a plan without defined source repository. The REST call : 

/rest/api/latest/queue/NT-NP.json 

returns an error:

Invalid return code received from Bamboo. 400: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?><status><status-code>400</status-code><message>Could not find a configured repository for 'NT-NP'. It may have been uninstalled. Plan 'NT-NP' did not start</message></status>

The configured task didn't have source repo provided. After creating a source repo I was able to run plan from JIRA.
fields.summary: JIRA Bamboo plugin can't build a plan without repo

fields.description:
While its nice that Bamboo automatically increments an integer on the end of the plan branch keys, it would be really nice to be able to choose the key on branch creation (certainly on manual branch creation) to allow more effective programmatic access to a group of branches.

The use case here is a number of plans tied together into a common release (RC1 for instance) in source control where I might want to make a RESTful call into Bamboo to get all the plan information and then filter on a pattern to get details of all the branches relevant to RC1 ... I know this can probably be done with plan labels, but more options would be nice.

(Currently, our problem is that plan 1 RC1 branch is number 0, but plan2 RC1 branch is number 1, for instance.)
fields.summary: Allow choice on branch plan keys

fields.description: A label applied _only_ to a branch plan but not to its master plan won't show up on the dashboard if the dashboard is filtered by that label. However, a master plan with the label still shows all its branches, regardless of their branch labels.
fields.summary: Dashboard filters show labels applied only to branch plans, but branch plans don't show up on the dashboard in that filter

fields.description: Similar to the mechanism on Plans themselves allowing a dropdown to switch between branches, having 1) the ability to specify on a branch name whether to enable this and 2) a dropdown on the dashboard itself to switch the view from the primary plans to a branch name would perhaps solve issues I raised in BAM-12259 and BAM-12262: We have dozens of plans in Bamboo that are either 1) all labeled together in Git for a release candidate or 2) could be all labeled together in Bamboo for a release candidate and hence could have their own common dashboard showing the status of the builds occurring for that common branch name or common label.
fields.summary: Plan Branch Dashboards and Filtered or Pivoted Views

fields.description:
Related to BAM-12259, it seems there almost no way to get a fast visual status of the state of all the builds across all the branches; both the dashboard and the wallboards seem to only show the status of the primary plan, regardless of the state of branch failures.

The use case I was looking into was to have release candidate builds be a branch of either our development or our production build plans, but in either case, the lack of visibility into the state of the branch plans makes it really difficult to use branches in this model.
fields.summary: Branch builds provide poor visual indicators of build status
